Award.AwardTitle: Manipulating Multi-Spin Dynamics in Systems Targeting Organic Spintronics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanism B (CSDM-B) program supports Professor Michael R. Wasielewski of Northwestern University to carry out fundamental studies on controlling the spin dynamics of complex multi-spin molecular systems that target spintronics and quantum information processing. Fast photo-initiated electron transfer within covalently-linked organic donor-acceptor molecules having specific donor-acceptor (D-A) distances and orientations results in the formation of spin-entangled electron-hole pairs (i.e. spin-correlated radical ion pairs, SCRPs) having well-defined initial spin configurations and magnetic spin-spin interactions. The project focuses on the demanding task of controlling spin coherence within organic molecular arrays using SCRPs in tailored covalent structures. The specific goals are to investigate: 1) What is the scope of spin coherence transfer by optical excitation of an SCRP? 2) What factors determine coherence dephasing in SCRPs? 3) Can coherent spin states be transported ("teleported") over long distances using SCRPs? 4) Can nuclear spins be used to store and retrieve coherent electron spin states produced by an SCRP?

Developing a fundamental understanding of how to control charge and spin transport through organized arrays of organic molecules is critical to the development of new electronics and spintronics especially with regard to their potential impact on computers and information processing. Taking advantage of the quantum nature of electron spin may lead to advanced computer technologies with broad applications throughout society. The use of organic materials and bio-inspired approaches to these problems offers the possibility of developing solutions that are not only versatile, but are cost effective and environmentally benign as well.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Spintronics, that is, spin-based electronics, uses the quantum spin property of electrons and/or nuclei to manipulate and transfer information. It thus offers the possibility of massively parallel information processing to address computational problems that would take today’s computer technology years to execute. Controlling the spin dynamics of complex multi-spin systems is a major goal in the quest for molecule-based spintronics. Developing a fundamental understanding of how to control charge and spin transport through organic molecules is critical to the future of electronics, computers, and energy production. The use of organic materials and bio-inspired approaches to these problems offers the possibility of developing solutions that are not only versatile, but are cost effective and environmentally benign as well.

Modern pulsed magnetic resonance techniques provide an important means of manipulating spin systems for potential spintronics applications. Moreover, photo-excitation of organic molecules has been shown to control their properties in a wide variety of photonics applications.  Photo-excitation of organic molecules can be used to produce well-defined initial spin states. For example, photo-initiated electron transfer on a picosecond time scale from a donor molecule to acceptor molecule that are covalently-linked to enforce a specific distance and orientation results in formation of a spin-correlated radical pair (SCRP) in which the initial spin state is well defined and the two spins of the SCRP exist in an entangled coherent state. A greater fundamental understanding of the factors controlling spin dynamics in complex, yet versatile organic multi-spin systems is necessary before construction of spintronic devices based on them is feasible. The specific goals of this project are to investigate four questions that are important for understanding spin coherence in organic SCRPs and their potential for the development of organic spintronics: 1) What is the scope of spin coherence transfer by optical excitation of a spin-correlated radical pair (SCRP)? 2) What factors determine coherence dephasing in SCRPs? 3) Can coherent spin states be transported (“teleported”) over long distances using SCRPs? 4) Can nuclear spins be used to store and retrieve coherent electron spin states produced by an SCRP? 

In this project, we have demonstrated that the initial formation of an SCRP using a laser pulse can be followed by a time-delayed second laser pulse that selectively excites one of the radicals within the SCRP.  This results in electron transfer from the photo-excited radical within the SCRP to a secondary electron acceptor. Even though the electron is moved spatially, it maintains spin coherence that is transferred to the more distant electron acceptor. We have also shown that spin coherence can be transferred between two stable organic radicals through the agency of an SCRP. In the molecule studied, laser excitation produces a SCRP that bridges two stable radicals, which turns on magnetic exchange coupling between the two stable radicals, allowing transfer of spin coherence between the radicals. The ability to control the flow of spin polarization and coherences in multi-spin assemblies is essential for the development of molecular spintronics. We have also demonstrated that other magnetic interactions, such as the dipole-dipole interaction between two spins can influence spin dynamics in a photo-generated three-spin system. We have also developed and extensively explored more complex structures based on mechanically-interlocked molecules that may ultimately serve as platforms on which to build nanoscale devices from the “bottom up” where several photo-generated SCRPs interact to process quantum information. Our future work will center on how to preserve and extend the lifetimes of spin coherent states in larger molecular assemblies.
